I have a series of commands I need to execute using a on a schedule... I understand I will use a cron job to execute the schedule... what do I do about the commands? I know in windows it would be something like a Batch file. Any ideas?
a simple shell script does the same thing as a batch file...
ah, Shell Script... I've heard that term before... thanks
are there a GUI for creating a cron job in ubuntu?
i would imagine there's several, but i don't know any off the top of my head
try searching in the synaptic package manager or add/remove for cron
simple shell scripting is really easy... create a file, add the commands, one per line, and make sure the file has execute permissions
add "#!/bin/bash" or "#!/bin/sh" to the top of the file (without quotes)
you can use regular expressions and logic and all that complicated bs, but if you just want to run a few commands at once, there's nothing special to do
here's a really nice guide for shell scripting http://tldp.org/LDP/abs/html/index.html
yes, as long as the systems you'll be running it on all have bash... nearly all linux distros have it

check out that link i gave if you want to do more complicated stuff than just run explicit commands... bash is very powerful at scripting... cgi uses perl, which is another scripting language, hence the similarities
if you're not using bash syntax, technically you don't need the bang at the top (#!/bin/bash), but get in the habit of it, as it is good practive
cd to the directory and run ./script.bash or whatever, or run it with the absolute path
to make it executable, the command is chmod u+x /path/to/file.bash
